Hi Jim,

Thank you for the fun kantei. I refrained to participate, but I mi=
ght add,
and I am pretty sure you are aware of this thinking, with Owari, t=
ekkotsu of
the type exhibited in your piece would prevent most Japanese col=
lectors from
considering anything but late Muromachi for the tsuba and not =
Momoyama or
early Edo. The same holds true for Kanayama. It is also interes=
ting that
some large Owari sukashi looking pieces have been attributed to K=
anayama, no
doubt based on the stylistic differences you pointed out. 

Fin=
ally, the link you gave is still to the Owari piece. Do you put up a new
ka=
ntei piece?

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogro=
ups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Jim Gilbert
Sent=
: Tuesday, March 07, 2006 12:44 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject=
: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei

The scan of the front of the guard does n=
ot do it justice, but is sufficient
to see what's there.  The photos of the=
 mimi give some sense of the tekkotsu
that place the guard in the Owari reg=
ion.  Given the shape of the rim and
the design, the two most likely choice=
s are Kanayama and Owari sukashi.  I
think either answer is acceptable give=
n that you are working from pictures.

The thickness and somewhat squared r=
im lean toward Kanayama, but can also be
seen in Owari work.  The guard is =
on the thick end of the spectrum for
either type.  The diameter is possible=
 for either group, although on the
large side for Kanayama.  The style of t=
he tekkotsu is the most important
point.  Kanayama tekkotsu tend to form pr=
onounced, sometimes rough bumps.
Owari tekkotsu are low, smooth and emerge =
from the plate with more subtlety,
forming "bean" shaped and "rope" forms. =
 This guard shows both of these
latter types.  Also, Kanayama guards will o=
ften show some tekkotsu on the
face, but Owari guards do not.

Wild goose d=
esigns are common in Owari work.  It's not impossible to imagine
a design l=
ike this in a Kanayama guard, but it is more naturalistic,
complicated and =
even a little delicate for that group.  The majority of the
evidence points=
 toward Owari sukashi.

The guard is in very good condition, so it may look=
 younger than it is.  The
quality of the iron and the tekkotsu are unlikely=
 to date to the early Edo
period, and are consistent with pieces from mid t=
o late Muromachi.  The
birds at the top and bottom of the sukashi design se=
em too free spirited to
be from that time, though and seem more like Momoya=
ma.  Given that design is
easier to manipulate than iron, I lean toward lat=
e Muromachi, but Momoyama
is possible.

The guard has a kanteisho to Owari =
from the NBTHK.  No date given.

Yagyu is in the correct region, but the te=
xture of the metal will be
cloudy/sandy and will tend to show many linear l=
aminations in the rim.  It
is also not a Yagyu design.

I included this tsu=
ba in the Akasaka display at Tampa to show the likely
Owari origins of the =
Akasaka group.  While some Ko-Akasaka guards will show
tekkotsu, they are n=
ot of this type and the color and texture of the iron is
different.  The ri=
m would show a more rounded shape in Akasaka.  The cutting
of the sukashi w=
ould have sharper edges.  The design does have a bit of
Akasaka feeling, bu=
t there would probably be more asymmetry and abstraction
in an Akasaka piec=
e.

That's all I can think of at the moment.  Any other observations or
que=
stions?

Jim



  OK, here is a guard for kantei:

  http://ph.groups.yahoo=
.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c

  77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 =
mm thick at the mimi and 7.1 mm thick at the
seppa dai.


  As far as I kno=
w it has not been published, but it has been exhibited at a
couple of study=
 meetings.  So, if you've already seen it and remember the
attribution, ple=
ase don't post the answer to the list.  It is mumei and
there are two almos=
t equally reasonable attributions, but I think that there
is more evidence =
for one than the other.

  Respond with your bid on or off list as you pref=
er.

  Jim
